title: Introduction to LDATree
text: Currently, LDATree offers two methods construct tree: first method utilizes direct-stopping rule, halting growth process specific conditions satisfied. second approach involves pruning: permits building larger tree, pruned using cross-validation.
code: # Build a tree using direct-stopping rule fit <- Treee(Species~., data = iris)  # Build a tree using cross-validation set.seed(443) fitCV <- Treee(Species~., data = iris, pruneMethod = "CV")

title: Introduction to LDATree
text: LDATree offers two plotting methods： can use plot directly view full tree diagram. check individual plot node interested , input (training) data specify node index.

title: Introduction to LDATree
code: # View the overall tree # plot(fit) # Tips: Try clicking on the nodes...

title: Introduction to LDATree
code: # Three types of individual plots # 1. Scatter plot on first two LD scores plot(fit, data = iris, node = 1) # 2. Density plot on the first LD score plot(fit, data = iris, node = 3) #> Warning: Groups with fewer than two data points have been dropped. #> Warning in max(ids, na.rm = TRUE): no non-missing arguments to max; returning #> -Inf # 3. A message plot(fit, data = iris, node = 5) #> [1] "Every observation in this node is predicted to be virginica"

title: Introduction to LDATree
code: # Prediction only predictions <- predict(fit, iris) head(predictions) #> [1] "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" # A more informative prediction predictions <- predict(fit, iris, type = "all") head(predictions) #>   response node setosa versicolor virginica #> 1   setosa   13      0          0         0 #> 2   setosa   13      0          0         0 #> 3   setosa   13      0          0         0 #> 4   setosa   13      0          0         0 #> 5   setosa   13      0          0         0 #> 6   setosa   13      0          0         0 # Experimental feature: LDAGrove # If you use CV to prune the tree, you can try an ensemble prediction predictions <- predict(fitCV, iris, type = "grove") head(predictions) #> [1] "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa"

title: Introduction to LDATree
text: missing values, need specify anything (unless want ); LDATree handle . default, fills missing numerical variables mean adds missing flag. missing factor variables, assigns new level. options, please refer help(Treee).
code: #  irisMissing <- iris for(i in 1:4) irisMissing[sample(150,20),i] <- NA fitMissing <- Treee(Species~., data = irisMissing) plot(fitMissing, data = irisMissing, node = 1)

title: Introduction to LDATree
text: re-implement LDA/GSVD apply model fitting, -product ldaGSVD function. Feel free play see compares MASS::lda.
code: fitLDAgsvd <- ldaGSVD(Species~., data = iris) predictionsLDAgsvd <- predict(fitLDAgsvd, newdata = iris) mean(predictionsLDAgsvd == iris$Species) #> [1] 0.98

what:
Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at
    Terminal Nodes
title:
Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at
    Terminal Nodes
text: LDATree R modeling package fitting classification trees. unfamiliar classification trees, tutorial traditional CART R implementation rpart.

title:
Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at
    Terminal Nodes
text: Compared similar trees, LDATree sets apart following ways: applies idea LDA (Linear Discriminant Analysis) selecting variables, finding splits, fitting models terminal nodes. addresses certain limitations R implementation LDA (MASS::lda), handling missing values, dealing features samples, constant values within groups. Re-implement LDA using Generalized Singular Value Decomposition (GSVD), LDATree offers quick response, particularly large datasets. package also includes several visualization tools provide deeper insights data.

title:
Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at
    Terminal Nodes

Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at
    Terminal Nodes
text: build LDATree: plot LDATree:    make predictions:
code: library(LDATree)  fit <- Treee(Species~., data = iris) # View the overall tree plot(fit) # Three types of individual plots # 1. Scatter plot on first two LD scores plot(fit, data = iris, node = 1) # 2. Density plot on the first LD score plot(fit, data = iris, node = 3) #> Warning: Groups with fewer than two data points have been dropped. #> Warning in max(ids, na.rm = TRUE): no non-missing arguments to max; returning #> -Inf # 3. A message plot(fit, data = iris, node = 5) #> [1] "Every observation in this node is predicted to be virginica" # Prediction only. predictions <- predict(fit, iris) head(predictions) #> [1] "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" "setosa" # A more informative prediction predictions <- predict(fit, iris, type = "all") head(predictions) #>   response node setosa   versicolor    virginica #> 1   setosa    7      1 1.346467e-26 5.470122e-41 #> 2   setosa    7      1 3.044310e-22 3.780883e-36 #> 3   setosa    7      1 1.602581e-24 7.965832e-39 #> 4   setosa    7      1 2.066476e-21 1.495780e-34 #> 5   setosa    7      1 3.323135e-27 1.520898e-41 #> 6   setosa    7      1 1.957386e-24 2.347768e-38

what: LDATree: Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at Terminal Nodes — LDATree-package
title: LDATree: Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at Terminal Nodes — LDATree-package
text: classification tree method uses LDA (Linear Discriminant Analysis) variable selection, split determination, model fitting terminal nodes. automatically handles missing values offers visualization tools.

title: LDATree: Classification Trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis at Terminal Nodes — LDATree-package
text: Maintainer: Siyu Wang swang739@wisc.edu (ORCID) [copyright holder]

what: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee
title: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee
text: Fit LDATree model.

title: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee
code: Treee(   formula,   data,   missingMethod = c("meanFlag", "newLevel"),   splitMethod = "LDscores",   pruneMethod = "none",   numberOfPruning = 10,   maxTreeLevel = 4,   minNodeSize = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee
text: formula object class formula, form class ~ x1 + x2 + ... data data frame contains predictors response. Missing values allowed predictors response. missingMethod Missing value solutions numerical variables factor variables. 'mean', 'median', 'meanFlag', 'medianFlag' available numerical variables. 'mode', 'modeFlag', 'newLevel' available factor variables. word 'Flag' methods indicates whether missing flag added . 'newLevel' method means missing values replaced new level rather imputing another existing value. splitMethod splitting rule LDATree growing process. now, 'LDscores' available option. pruneMethod model selection method LDATree growing process, controls size tree. default, set 'none', applies direct stopping rule. Alternatively, 'CV' uses alpha-pruning process CART. Although 'CV' often accurate, can slower, especially large datasets. numberOfPruning controls number cross-validation pruning. 10 default. maxTreeLevel controls largest tree size possible either direct-stopping tree CV-pruned tree. Adding one extra level (depth) introduces additional layer nodes bottom current tree. e.g., maximum level 1 (2), maximum tree size 3 (7). minNodeSize controls minimum node size. Think carefully changing value. Setting large number might result early stopping reduced accuracy. default, set one plus number classes response variable. verbose logical. TRUE, function provides additional diagnostic messages detailed output progress internal workings. Default FALSE, function runs silently without additional output.

title: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee
text: object class Treee containing following components: formula: formula passed Treee() treee: list tree nodes, node object class TreeeNode. missingMethod: missingMethod passed Treee() object class TreeeNode containing following components: currentIndex: node index current node currentLevel: level current node tree idxRow, idxCol: row column indices showing portion data used current node currentLoss: training error (number misclassified sample) current node accuracy: training accuracy current node proportions: shows observed frequency class parent: node index parent children: node indices direct children (including children's children) misReference: data frame, serves reference missing value imputation splitCut: cut point split nodeModel: one 'mode' 'LDA'. shows type predictive model fitted current node nodePredict: fitted predictive model current node. object class ldaGSVD LDA fitted. nodeModel = 'mode', vector length one, showing plurality class. offsprings: (available pruneMethod = 'CV') showing terminal descendant nodes current node offspringLoss: (available pruneMethod = 'CV') sum currentLoss offsprings current node alpha: (available pruneMethod = 'CV') alpha alpha-pruning CART

title: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee
text: Unlike classification trees, LDATree integrates LDA throughout entire tree-growing process. breakdown distinctive features: tree searches best binary split based sample quantiles first linear discriminant score. LDA/GSVD model fitted terminal node (details, refer ldaGSVD()). Missing values can imputed using mean, median, mode, optional missing flags available. default, tree employs direct-stopping rule. However, cross-validation using alpha-pruning CART also provided.

title: Classification trees with Linear Discriminant Analysis terminal nodes — Treee

what:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD
title:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD
text: Fit LDA/GSVD model.

title:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD

Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD
text: formula object class formula, form class ~ x1 + x2 + ... data data frame contains predictors response. Missing values allowed.

title:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD
text: object class ldaGSVD containing following components: scaling: matrix transforms training data LD scores, normalized within-group scatter matrix proportional identity matrix. formula: formula passed ldaGSVD() terms: object class terms derived using input formula training data prior: table estimated prior probabilities. groupMeans: matrix records group means training data transformed LD scores. xlevels: list records levels factor predictors, derived using input formula training data

title:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD
text: Traditional Fisher's Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) ceases work within-class scatter matrix singular. Generalized Singular Value Decomposition (GSVD) used address issue. GSVD simultaneously diagonalizes within-class -class scatter matrices without need invert singular matrix. method believed accurate PCA-LDA (MASS::lda) also considers information -class scatter matrix.

title:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD
text: Ye, J., Janardan, R., Park, C. H., & Park, H. (2004). optimization criterion generalized discriminant analysis undersampled problems. IEEE Transactions Pattern Analysis Machine Intelligence Howland, P., Jeon, M., & Park, H. (2003). Structure preserving dimension reduction clustered text data based generalized singular value decomposition. SIAM Journal Matrix Analysis Applications

title:
Linear Discriminant Analysis using the Generalized Singular Value
Decomposition — ldaGSVD

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee
text: Provide diagram whole tree structure scatter/density plot specific tree node.

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee
code: # S3 method for Treee plot(x, data, node = -1, ...)

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee
text: x fitted model object class Treee, assumed result Treee() function. data original data used fit Treee object want individual plot node. Otherwise, can leave parameter blank need overall tree structure diagram. node node index interested . default, set -1 overall tree structure drawn. ... arguments passed methods.

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee
text: overall tree structure (node = -1), figure class visNetwork drawn. Otherwise, figure class ggplot drawn.

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee
text: full tree diagram (via R package visNetwork) shown node provided (default -1). color shows common (plurality) class inside node. size terminal node based relative sample size. every node, see plurality class, fraction correctly predicted training sample vs. node's sample size, node index, respectively. click node, information panel details appear.

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee
text: node index original training data required return detailed plot within specific node. density plot provided two levels left response variable node (like binary classification problem). Samples projected first linear discriminant scores (LD1). scatter plot provided node contains two classes. Samples projected first second linear discriminant scores.

title: Plot a Treee object — plot.Treee

title: Predictions from a fitted Treee object — predict.Treee
text: object fitted model object class Treee, assumed result Treee() function. newdata data frame containing values predictions required. Missing values allowed. type character string denoting type predicted value returned. default return predicted class (type = 'response'). predicted posterior probabilities class returned type = 'prob'. '' returns data frame predicted classes, posterior probabilities, predicted node indices. cross-validation carried LDATree fitting, 'grove' option available output ensemble result k LDATrees k number cross-validation. ... arguments passed methods.

title: Predictions from a fitted Treee object — predict.Treee
text: function returns different values based type, type = 'response': vector predicted responses. type = 'prob': data frame posterior probabilities. class takes column. type = '': data frame contains predicted responses, posterior probabilities, predicted node indices. type = 'grove': vector predicted responses using ensemble method. available cross-validation carried tree generating process. Note: factor predictors, contains level used grow tree, converted missing imputed according missingMethod fitted tree.

title: Predictions from a fitted ldaGSVD object — predict.ldaGSVD
text: function returns different values based type, type = 'response': vector predicted responses. type = 'prob': data frame posterior probabilities. class takes column.

title: Predictions from a fitted ldaGSVD object — predict.ldaGSVD
text: Unlike original paper, uses k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) classifier, use faster straightforward likelihood-based method. One limitation traditional likelihood-based method LDA ceases work Linear Discriminant (LD) directions zero variance within-class scatter matrix. However, using LDA/GSVD, chosen LD directions possess non-zero variance -class scatter matrix. implies LD directions zero variance within-class scatter matrix yield highest Fisher's ratio. Therefore, get directions higher weights, manually adjust zero variance 1e-15 computational reasons.
